subject: RE: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Because my production code parses this XML, so I want my test to do the same. ... And then one day, an XML driver is missing on my production code but my
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> > For example, imagine that the class to test does some verification on
> > an XML file. In this case, the one-time set up should simply parse
> > the XML file, create the DOM tree and then use the class to perform
> > various verifications on this tree. And of course, we don't want to
> > re-parse it every time.
>
> If you don't want to test the XML to object mapping, then why
> bother with XML at all in the test?

Because my production code parses this XML, so I want my test to do the
same.

> Just create a bunch of objects to play with and skip the XML part.

And then one day, an XML driver is missing on my production code but my
tests are still all happily green because they are using mock objects.

Why is it so hard to understand that I want my tests to be as close to my
production code as possible?!?

> Please give an example where it does affect your test results
> if the setup code runs for each test and where you still
> claim that the tests are independent.

How about the example I just gave?

Hint: imagine the XML file is several megabytes big. It's not that far
fetched, really.
